awd_titl_txt: FET: Small: Stochastic Synthesis of Peptides and Small Molecules
awd_abstract_narration:
This project accelerates the development of new drugs. Currently, the process of developing a new drug takes an average of 12 years and tens or hundreds of millions of dollars. Consequently, only a handful of new drugs enter the market every year. It is essential to bring the level of automation inherent in computing disciplines to the life sciences. The search space for possibly beneficial and life-saving biomolecules is enormous. The proposed approach will ensure that only biomolecules likely to satisfy the desired properties are enumerated and empirically evaluated. Accelerated growth in the pharmaceutical industry strengthens the US economy by creating desirable biotechnology jobs, and increases our overall global competitiveness in biotechnology.

This project applies program synthesis principles to automate the discovery of new drugs. The chemist is allowed to specify the characteristics of the desired drug using a domain-specific specification language. For example, a chemist developing a novel peptide drug (a sequence of amino-acids) may request that amino acids at specific positions have certain chemical properties, or that certain constant sequences of amino acids with known behaviors appear in specific locations in the peptide. The chemist can also specify the target proteins in the mix to which the peptide drug should or should not bind. The binding strength of a drug translates to its efficacy. Given a drug specification, the synthesis process automatically identifies a ligand that complies with the specification, can be safely synthesized and strongly binds to the desired proteins.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project applied principles of program synthesis---that is, automating the creation of a provably correct program for a user-specified task---to automate the discovery of feasible chemical synthesis pathways for new drugs. The development of new pharmaceuticals improves our quality of life and drives growth in the $500 billion US pharmaceutical industry. Drug developers have many software tools that help with designing new drugs, but figuring out how to actually make the drugs (chemical synthesis) is a time-consuming and capital- and labor-intensive process. This process shares some principle similarity to software development: it might be non-trivial to identify the need for a new software application, but substantially more challenging to design, implement, and validate the application itself. 

This project has yielded a variety of useful hardware and software artifacts. These include:

PepSyn:  an approach to pharmaceutical discovery based on proven techniques in program synthesis and superoptimization in which the user can specify either a template of the primary structure of a desired drug using a domain-specific language (PepSketch), or specify a set of example peptide drugs (PepGen), both of which seed a heuristic search for pharmaceutical property optimization. 

BioScript: A domain-specific programming language and compiler targeting programmable laboratory-on-chip devices. Bioscript is simple, intuitive, and type-safe, which make it accessible to life science practitioners. It's syntax is optimized for human readability, and its type system ensures the certain types of errors, specific to biochemistry, do not occur, such as the interaction of chemicals that may be unsafe. 

ChemStor:  An open-source, automated computational system which can mathematically guarantee safe storage and disposal of chemical used in academic, industrial and domestic settings. ChemStore applies formal methods, a branch of computer science capable of mathematically proving correctness of software or a specification, to safely store and dispose of chemicals. 

Directed placement algorithms for continuous-flow microfluidic devices based on integrated channel networks, which were previously laid out by hand by domain experts who understand both the underlying technology and the biological functions that will execute on fabricated devices. Directed placement creates physical layouts that share many principle similarities to those created by domain experts and allows components to be placed closer to their neighbors compared to existing layout algorithms based on planar graph embedding or simulated annealing.

Multi-objective design automation software to enable the rapid design of microfluidic capture chips, which are useful for preparing or analyzing a wide range of different chemical, biological, and medical samples. Creating optimal capture chip designs is difficult because of the inherent relationship between capture efficiency and flow resistance. Multi-objective optimization can generate capture chip designs that balance the trade-offs between these two metrics. 

A method for measuring the dissolution profiles of controlled-release substances from single controlled-release pellets across a variety of conditions, as recommended by the US Food and Drug Administration. By measuring any controlled-release pellets, particles, beads, or granules in any physiologically-relevant environment in a fully-automated fashion, this method can augment and potentially replace current dissolution tests and support product development and quality assurance in the pharmaceutical industry.

A new fluid mechanics model describing the behavior of microchips flowing in microfluidic channels for drug synthesis applications, such as hydrodynamic sorting, which is essential in microfluidic systems used for applications requiring particle-based multiplexing. This model is in good agreement with the generalized particle lift-off model and allows for prediction offlat-plate particle lift-off in microfluidic channels. 

A new use for poly(dimethylsiloxane) (PDMS) aka "silicone rubber" as a "solid solvent" in biological and chemical applications. While PDMS is broadly used to fabricate microfluidic devices, it swells in organic solvents, limiting it use for applications employing non-aqueous fluids. The swelling is reversible, which benefits loading samples into the PDMS solid matrix, which allows PDMS to serve a solid solvent for optical applications.

Microfluidic hardware designs for detecting errors in the operation of pneumatically controlled hardware, where undetected failures can have serious consequences. By providing a simple and low-cost way to detect problems without using sensors, the pneumatic error detector can promote safety and reliability across a wide range of pneumatic systems. 

Microfluidic valve designs suitable for making pneumatic logic circuits capable of controlling biomedical devices using flowing air (and no electricity). A high-flow pneumatic oscillator constructed from these valves can power a low-cost 3D-printed laboratory rocker/shaker commonly used to keep blood products, cell cultures, and other heterogeneous samples in suspension, which costs around $12 USD, compared to conventional rockers which cost $1000 USD or more. 

A microfluidic random access memory (RAM) for controlling soft robots, which have advantages of traditional rigid robots in many applications. The pneumatic memory sets and maintain the states of large numbers of soft robotic actuators without dedicated electromechanical hardware, dramatically reducing the amount of hardware required to control multiple independent actuators in pneumatic soft robots.
